newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada govt asks CRTC to consider new TV networks.
newsitem.headline: Canada govt asks CRTC to consider new TV networks.

text.p: The Canadian government has formally requested the broadcast regulatory agency CRTC to study the possibility of the establishment of new national television networks.
A statement from Canadian Heritage Minister Sheila Copps, received late on Thursday, noted that she had first announced the government's intention to do so on January 28.

On that day, the cabinet denied an appeal by CanWest Global Communications Corp of a decision by the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission (CRTC) denying it a television license in Alberta, which would have helped it establish a presence across Canada.

The CRTC chose the small company Craig Broadcast Systems Inc and Copps said at the time it was a valid individual licensing decision, but that the question of adding national television networks needed to be examined.
"The goal of the Broadcasting Act, and the goal of this government, is to increase the quantity and quality of Canadian programming in both official languages," Copps said on Thursday.

"I want to ensure that over-the-air broadcasters, whether as parts of networks or as parts of station ownership groups, continue to provide a clear reflection of our country both on a regional and a national basis."
She added: "In a world of expanding viewer choices, it is vital that quality Canadian programming remain available and attractive to Canadian audiences."
The CRTC will have to hold hearings, seek public comment and report back to the government on issues and options related to the possible establishment of new networks.
